gnu.cajo.invoke
Interface Invoke

All Superinterfaces:
java.io.Serializable
All Known Subinterfaces:
RemoteInvoke
All Known Implementing Classes:
BaseProxy, Client, MonitorItem, ProxyLoader, Remote, ZippedProxy
public interface Invoke
extends java.io.Serializable

The generic inter-component communication interface, and foundation for this paradigm. This provides a standard communication interface between components, referred to in this package as items. It is used to pass arguments to, and recieve synchronous responses from, the receiving item.

The implementation is so extrmely simple, it's included here:

 public interface Invoke extends Serializable {
   Object invoke(String method, Object args[]) throws Exception;
 }

Version:
1.0, 01-Nov-99 Initial release
Author:
John Catherino

Method Summary
 java.lang.Object invoke(java.lang.String method, java.lang.Object args)
          Used by other items to pass data into this item, and receive synchronous data responses from it, if any.
 

Method Detail

invoke

public java.lang.Object invoke(java.lang.String method,
                               java.lang.Object args)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
Used by other items to pass data into this item, and receive synchronous data responses from it, if any. The invocation may, or may not contain inbound data. It may, or may not, return a data object response. The functionality of this method is completely application specific. This interface only serves to define the format of communication between items.

Note: this method could be called reentrantly, by many items, simultaneously. If this would cause a problem, the critical sections of this item's method must be synchronized. In general, synchronizing the whole method is strongly discouraged, as it could block multiple clients too easily.

Parameters:
method - A key to the meaning of the invocation, possibly even null.
args - The data relevant to the operation. It can be a single object, an array, or even null.
Returns:
Any synchronous data defined by a subclass' implementation, possibly even null
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - As needed by the application. Note: subclasses of Exception can be thrown, to allow client items the opportunity to catch only specific types, these exceptions might also contain application specific methods, and fields, to supplement the error information. If an item does not throw any exceptions, it would be preferable to simply omit the throws clause entirely, in the subclass' method declaration.
